question_text: A 27-year-old man is evaluated for painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Four weeks ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that healed spontaneously.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is lymphogranuloma venereum (Option B), a urogenital infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Primary infection is typically characterized by a genital ulcer that heals spontaneously. Secondary manifestations appear within 2 to 6 weeks and are characterized by infection of the inguinal and/or femoral nodes. This image depicts a close anterior view of a patient's right inguinal region, highlighting the presence of an enlarged inguinal lymph node, also known as a bubo. It is important to note the presence of a groove sign, caused by the extreme swelling of the lymph nodes pressing against the taught inguinal ligament, which causes a groove to form on the skin surface.
